pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:0.5.eng: 5. The training rule on receiving robes

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.1.eng: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena uppalavaṇṇā bhikkhunī sāvatthiyaṃ viharati.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.2.eng: the nun Uppalavaṇṇā was staying at Sāvatthī.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.3.pli: Atha kho uppalavaṇṇā bhikkhunī pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.3.eng: One morning she robed up, took her bowl and robe, and entered Sāvatthī to collect almsfood.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.4.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena andhavanaṃ tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.4.eng: When she had completed her almsround, eaten her meal, and returned, she went to the Blind Men’s Grove

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.5.pli: Andhavanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.5.eng: where she sat down at the foot of a tree for the day’s meditation.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.6.pli: Tena kho pana samayena corā katakammā gāviṃ vadhitvā maṃsaṃ gahetvā andhavanaṃ pavisiṃsu.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.6.eng: Just then some bandits who had stolen and slaughtered a cow were taking the meat to the Blind Men’s Grove.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.7.pli: Addasā kho coragāmaṇiko uppalavaṇṇaṃ bhikkhuniṃ aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisinnaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.7.eng: The head bandit saw Uppalavaṇṇā sitting at the foot of that tree.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.9.pli: “sace me puttabhātukā passissanti viheṭhissanti imaṃ bhikkhunin”ti
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.9.eng: “If my sons and brothers see this nun, they’ll harass her,”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.10.eng: and he took a different path.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.11.pli: Atha kho so coragāmaṇiko maṃse pakke varamaṃsāni gahetvā paṇṇapuṭaṃ bandhitvā uppalavaṇṇāya bhikkhuniyā avidūre rukkhe ālaggetvā—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.11.eng: Soon afterwards when the meat was cooked, he took the best part, tied it up with a palm-leaf wrap, hung it from a tree not far from Uppalavaṇṇā, and said,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.12.pli: “yo passati samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā dinnaṃyeva haratū”ti, vatvā pakkāmi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.12.eng: “Whatever ascetic or brahmin sees this gift, please take it.” And he left.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.13.pli: Assosi kho uppalavaṇṇā bhikkhunī samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā tassa coragāmaṇikassa imaṃ vācaṃ bhāsamānassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.13.eng: Uppalavaṇṇā had just come out from the stillness of meditation when she heard the head bandit making that statement.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.14.pli: Atha kho uppalavaṇṇā bhikkhunī taṃ maṃsaṃ gahetvā upassayaṃ agamāsi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.14.eng: She took the meat and returned to her dwelling place.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.15.pli: Atha kho uppalavaṇṇā bhikkhunī tassā rattiyā accayena taṃ maṃsaṃ sampādetvā uttarāsaṅgena bhaṇḍikaṃ bandhitvā vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā veḷuvane paccuṭṭhāsi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.1.15.eng: The following morning she prepared the meat and made it into a bundle with her upper robe. She then rose into the air and landed in the Bamboo Grove.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā gāmaṃ piṇḍāya paviṭṭho hoti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.1.eng: When she arrived, the Buddha had already gone to the village for alms,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.2.eng: but Venerable Udāyī had been left behind to look after the dwellings.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.3.pli: Atha kho uppalavaṇṇā bhikkhunī yenāyasmā udāyī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.5.eng: “He’s gone to the village for alms.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.6.eng: “Please give this meat to the Buddha.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.7.eng: “You’ll please the Buddha with that meat.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.8.pli: Sace me tvaṃ antaravāsakaṃ dadeyyāsi, evaṃ ahampi santappito bhaveyyaṃ antaravāsakenā”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.8.eng: If you give me your sarong, you’ll please me too.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.9.pli: “Mayaṃ kho, bhante, mātugāmā nāma kicchalābhā. Idañca me antimaṃ pañcamaṃ cīvaraṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.9.eng: “It’s hard for women to get material support, and this is one of my five robes. I don’t have another.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.11.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhagini, puriso hatthiṃ datvā kacche sajjeyya;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.11.eng: “Sister, just as a man giving an elephant might decorate it with a girdle,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.12.pli: evameva kho tvaṃ, bhagini, bhagavato maṃsaṃ datvā mayi antaravāsake sajjasī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.12.eng: so should you, when giving meat to the Buddha, decorate me with your sarong.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.13.pli: Atha kho uppalavaṇṇā bhikkhunī āyasmatā udāyinā nippīḷiyamānā antaravāsakaṃ datvā upassayaṃ agamāsi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.13.eng: Being pressured by Udāyī, Uppalavaṇṇā gave him her sarong and then returned to her dwelling place.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.14.pli: Bhikkhuniyo uppalavaṇṇāya bhikkhuniyā pattacīvaraṃ paṭiggaṇhantiyo uppalavaṇṇaṃ bhikkhuniṃ etadavocuṃ—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.14.eng: The nuns who received Uppalavaṇṇā’s bowl and robe asked her

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.16.eng: And she told them what had happened.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.17.eng: The nuns complained and criticized Udāyī,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.18.pli: “kathañhi nāma ayyo udāyī bhikkhuniyā cīvaraṃ paṭiggahessati kicchalābho mātugāmo”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.18.eng: “How could Venerable Udāyī receive a robe from a nun? It’s hard for women to get material support.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.19.pli: Atha kho tā bhikkhuniyo bhikkhūnaṃ etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.20.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.20.eng: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.21.pli: “kathañhi nāma āyasmā udāyī bhikkhuniyā cīvaraṃ paṭiggahessatī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.21.eng: “How could Venerable Udāyī receive a robe from a nun?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.22.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ anekapariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.22.eng: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Udāyī:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.23.pli: “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, udāyi, bhikkhuniyā cīvaraṃ paṭiggahesī”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.23.eng: “Is it true, Udāyī, that you did this?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.27.pli: “Aññātako, moghapurisa, aññātikāya na jānāti patirūpaṃ vā appatirūpaṃ vā santaṃ vā asantaṃ vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.27.eng: “Foolish man, a man and a woman who are unrelated don’t know what’s appropriate and inappropriate, what’s good and bad, in dealing with each other.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.28.pli: Tattha nāma tvaṃ, moghapurisa, aññātikāya bhikkhuniyā hatthato cīvaraṃ paṭiggahessasi.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.30.pli: evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ uddiseyyātha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.30.eng: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.31.1.pli: “Yo pana bhikkhu aññātikāya bhikkhuniyā hatthato cīvaraṃ paṭiggaṇheyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyan”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.31.1.eng: ‘If a monk receives a robe directly from an unrelated nun, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.32.pli: Evañcidaṃ bhagavatā bhikkhūnaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ paññattaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:1.2.32.eng: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū kukkuccāyantā bhikkhunīnaṃ pārivattakacīvaraṃ na paṭiggaṇhanti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.1.eng: Then, being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not receive robes from nuns even in exchange.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.2.eng: The nuns complained and criticized them,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.3.pli: “kathañhi nāma ayyā amhākaṃ pārivattakacīvaraṃ na paṭiggahessantī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.3.eng: “How can they not receive robes from us in exchange?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.4.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tāsaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ ujjhāyantīnaṃ khiyyantīnaṃ vipācentīnaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.4.eng: The monks heard the criticism of those nuns

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.5.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.6.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.7.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ pārivattakaṃ paṭiggahetuṃ— bhikkhussa, bhikkhuniyā, sikkhamānāya, sāmaṇerassa, sāmaṇeriyā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.7.eng: “Monks, I allow you to receive things in exchange from five kinds of people: monks, nuns, trainee nuns, novice monks, and novice nuns.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.8.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, imesaṃ pañcannaṃ pārivattakaṃ paṭiggahetuṃ.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.9.pli: Evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ uddiseyyātha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.9.eng: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.10.1.pli: “Yo pana bhikkhu aññātikāya bhikkhuniyā hatthato cīvaraṃ paṭiggaṇheyya, aññatra pārivattakā, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyan”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:2.10.1.eng: ‘If a monk receives a robe directly from an unrelated nun, except in exchange, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.4.eng: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.6.pli: mātito vā pitito vā yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā asambaddhā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.6.eng: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back eight generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.6.comm: Sp 1.505: Tattha yāva sattamā pitāmahayugāti pitupitā pitāmaho, pitāmahassa yugaṁ pitāmahayugaṁ, “In this yāva sattamā pitāmahayuga means: the father of a father is a grandfather. The generation of a grandfather is called a pitāmahayuga.” So the PaIi phrase yāva sattamā pitāmahayuga means “as far as the seventh generation of grandfathers”, that is, eight generations back. This can be counted as follows: (1) one’s grandfather; (2) his father; (3) 2’s father; (4) 3’s father; (5) 4’s father; (6) 5’s father; and (7) 6’s father. This applies to both one’s paternal and maternal grandfathers. This gives a total of 14 ancestors. Anyone who is a descendent of these fourteen is considered a relative. Anyone who is not such a descendent is not regarded as a relative.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.8.eng: she has been given the full ordination by both Sanghas.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.10.pli: channaṃ cīvarānaṃ aññataraṃ cīvaraṃ vikappanupagaṃ pacchimaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.10.eng: one of the six kinds of robe-cloth, but not smaller than what can be assigned to another.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.10.comm: The six are linen, cotton, silk, wool, sunn hemp, and hemp; see Kd 8:3.1.6. According to Kd 8:21.1.4, the size referred to here is no smaller than 8 by 4 sugataṅgula, “standard fingerbreadths”. For an explanation of the idea of vikappanā, see Appendix of Technical Terms. For the rendering of cīvara as “robe-cloth”, see the same appendix.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.13.eng: If he accepts, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.14.eng: When he gets the robe-cloth, it becomes subject to relinquishment.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.15.pli: Nissajjitabbaṃ saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā puggalassa vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.15.eng: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.16.eng: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.17.eng: (To be expanded as in Bu NP 1:3.2.5–3.2.29, with appropriate substitutions.)

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.18.pli: idaṃ me, bhante, cīvaraṃ aññātikāya bhikkhuniyā hatthato paṭiggahitaṃ, aññatra pārivattakā, nissaggiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.18.eng: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth, which I received directly from an unrelated nun without anything in exchange, is to be relinquished.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.19.eng: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.1.22.eng: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.1.pli: Aññātikāya aññātikasaññī cīvaraṃ paṭiggaṇhāti, aññatra pārivattakā, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.1.eng: If she is unrelated and he perceives her as such, and he receives robe-cloth from her, except in exchange, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.2.pli: Aññātikāya vematiko cīvaraṃ paṭiggaṇhāti, aññatra pārivattakā, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.2.eng: If she is unrelated, but he is unsure of it, and he receives robe-cloth from her, except in exchange, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.3.pli: Aññātikāya ñātikasaññī cīvaraṃ paṭiggaṇhāti, aññatra pārivattakā, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.3.eng: If she is unrelated, but he perceives her as related, and he receives robe-cloth from her, except in exchange, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.4.pli: Ekatoupasampannāya hatthato cīvaraṃ paṭiggaṇhāti, aññatra pārivattakā, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.4.eng: If he receives robe-cloth directly from a nun who is fully ordained only on one side, except in exchange, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.5.eng: If she is related, but he perceives her as unrelated, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.6.eng: If she is related, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.2.7.eng: If she is related and he perceives her as such, there is no offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.3.pli: pārivattakaṃ parittena vā vipulaṃ, vipulena vā parittaṃ,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.3.eng: if much is exchanged with little or little is exchanged with much;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.4.eng: if he takes it on trust;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.4.comm: This refers to a situation where you have an agreement with a close friend that you may take their belongings on trust. The conditions for taking on trust are set out at Kd 8:19.1.5.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.6.eng: if he receives any requisite apart from robe-cloth;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.7.eng: if it is a trainee nun;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.8.eng: if it is a novice nun;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.10.eng: if he is the first offender.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np5:3.3.11.eng: The training rule on receiving robes, the fifth, is finished.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:0.5.eng: 6. The training rule on asking non-relations

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā upanando sakyaputto paṭṭo hoti dhammiṃ kathaṃ kātuṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.2.eng: At that time Venerable Upananda the Sakyan was skilled at teaching.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.3.pli: Atha kho aññataro seṭṭhiputto yenāyasmā upanando sakyaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ upanandaṃ sakyaputtaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.3.eng: On one occasion the son of a wealthy merchant went to Upananda, bowed, and sat down.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho taṃ seṭṭhiputtaṃ āyasmā upanando sakyaputto dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.4.eng: And Upananda instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.5.pli: Atha kho so seṭṭhiputto āyasmatā upanandena sakyaputtena dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito āyasmantaṃ upanandaṃ sakyaputtaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.5.eng: Afterwards that merchant’s son said to Upananda:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.6.eng: “Venerable, please tell me what you need.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.7.eng: I can give you robe-cloth, almsfood, a dwelling, and medicinal supplies.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.8.pli: “Sace me tvaṃ, āvuso, dātukāmosi, ito ekaṃ sāṭakaṃ dehī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.8.eng: “If you wish to give me something, give me one of your wrap garments.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.9.pli: “Amhākaṃ kho, bhante, kulaputtānaṃ kismiṃ viya ekasāṭakaṃ gantuṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.9.eng: “It’s shameful, venerable, for a gentleman to walk around in only one wrap.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.10.eng: Please wait until I get back home.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.11.pli: Gharaṃ gato ito vā ekaṃ sāṭakaṃ pahiṇissāmi ito vā sundarataran”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.11.eng: I’ll send you this wrap or a better one.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.12.pli: Dutiyampi kho āyasmā upanando sakyaputto taṃ seṭṭhiputtaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.13.pli: “sace me tvaṃ, āvuso, dātukāmosi ito ekaṃ sāṭakaṃ dehī”ti.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.14.pli: Amhākaṃ kho bhante kulaputtānaṃ kismiṃ viya ekasāṭakaṃ gantuṃ, āgamehi, bhante yāva gharaṃ gacchāmi, gharaṃ gato ito vā ekaṃ sāṭakaṃ pahiṇissāmi ito vā sundarataranti.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.15.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmā upanando sakyaputto taṃ seṭṭhiputtaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.15.eng: and a third time Upananda said

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.16.pli: “sace me tvaṃ, āvuso, dātukāmosi, ito ekaṃ sāṭakaṃ dehī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.16.eng: the same thing to that merchant’s son,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.17.pli: Amhākaṃ kho, bhante, kulaputtānaṃ kismiṃ viya ekasāṭakaṃ gantuṃ, āgamehi, bhante yāva gharaṃ gacchāmi, gharaṃ gato ito vā ekaṃ sāṭakaṃ pahiṇissāmi ito vā sundarataranti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.17.eng: and he got the same reply.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.18.pli: “Kiṃ pana tayā, āvuso, adātukāmena pavāritena yaṃ tvaṃ pavāretvā na desī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.18.eng: He then said, “What’s the point of inviting me if you don’t want to give?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.19.pli: Atha kho so seṭṭhiputto āyasmatā upanandena sakyaputtena nippīḷiyamāno ekaṃ sāṭakaṃ datvā agamāsi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.19.eng: Being pressured by Upananda, that merchant’s son gave him one of his wraps and left.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.1.pli: Manussā taṃ seṭṭhiputtaṃ etadavocuṃ—“kissa tvaṃ, ayyo, ekasāṭako āgacchasī”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.1.eng: People asked him why he was walking around in only one wrap,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.2.pli: Atha kho so seṭṭhiputto tesaṃ manussānaṃ etamatthaṃ ārocesi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.2.eng: and he told them what had happened.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.4.eng: “These Sakyan monastics have great desires. They’re not content.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.5.eng: Even to make them an appropriate offer isn’t easy.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.6.pli: Kathañhi nāma seṭṭhiputtena dhammanimantanāya kayiramānāya sāṭakaṃ gahessantī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.6.eng: How could they take his wrap when the merchant’s son was making an appropriate offer?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.7.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ manussānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.7.eng: The monks heard the complaints of those people,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.8.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.8.eng: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized Upananda,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.9.pli: “kathañhi nāma āyasmā upanando sakyaputto seṭṭhiputtaṃ cīvaraṃ viññāpessatī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.9.eng: “How could Venerable Upananda ask the merchant’s son for a robe?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.10.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ upanandaṃ sakyaputtaṃ anekapariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.10.eng: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Upananda:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.11.pli: “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, upananda, seṭṭhiputtaṃ cīvaraṃ viññāpesī”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.11.eng: “Is it true, Upananda, that you did this?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.15.pli: “Aññātako, moghapurisa, aññātakassa na jānāti patirūpaṃ vā appatirūpaṃ vā santaṃ vā asantaṃ vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.15.eng: “Foolish man, people who are unrelated don’t know what’s appropriate and inappropriate, what’s good and bad, in dealing with each other.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.16.pli: Tattha nāma tvaṃ, moghapurisa, aññātakaṃ seṭṭhiputtaṃ cīvaraṃ viññāpessasi.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.18.pli: evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ uddiseyyātha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.18.eng: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.19.1.pli: “Yo pana bhikkhu aññātakaṃ gahapatiṃ vā gahapatāniṃ vā cīvaraṃ viññāpeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyan”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.19.1.eng: ‘If a monk asks an unrelated male or female householder for a robe, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.20.pli: Evañcidaṃ bhagavatā bhikkhūnaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ paññattaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.20.eng: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū sāketā sāvatthiṃ addhānamaggappaṭipannā honti. Antarāmagge corā nikkhamitvā te bhikkhū acchindiṃsu.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.1.eng: Soon afterwards a number of monks who were traveling from Sāketa to Sāvatthī were robbed by bandits.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.2.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū—“bhagavatā paṭikkhittaṃ aññātakaṃ gahapatiṃ vā gahapatāniṃ vā cīvaraṃ viññāpetun”ti, kukkuccāyantā na viññāpesuṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.2.eng: Knowing that the Buddha had laid down this training rule and being afraid of wrongdoing, they did not ask for robes.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.3.eng: As a consequence, they walked naked to Sāvatthī, where they bowed down to the monks.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.4.pli: Bhikkhū evamāhaṃsu—“sundarā kho ime, āvuso, ājīvakā ye ime bhikkhūsu abhivādentī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.4.eng: The monks there said, “These Ājīvaka ascetics are good people, as they bow down to the monks.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.5.pli: Te evamāhaṃsu—“na mayaṃ, āvuso, ājīvakā, bhikkhū mayan”ti.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.6.pli: Bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ upāliṃ etadavocuṃ—“iṅghāvuso upāli, ime anuyuñjāhī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.6.eng: The monks asked Venerable Upāli to examine them.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.7.pli: Atha kho āyasmatā upālinā anuyuñjiyamānā te bhikkhū etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ. Atha kho āyasmā upāli te bhikkhū anuyuñjitvā bhikkhū etadavoca—“bhikkhū ime, āvuso. Detha nesaṃ cīvarānī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.7.eng: When the naked monks told him what had happened, Upāli said to the monks, “They are monks. Please give them robes.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.8.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.8.eng: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.10.pli: Nanu nāma tiṇena vā paṇṇena vā paṭicchādetvā āgantabban”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.10.eng: Shouldn’t they have covered up with grass and leaves?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.11.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū te anekapariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.11.eng: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.12.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.12.eng: Soon afterwards he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.13.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, acchinnacīvarassa vā naṭṭhacīvarassa vā aññātakaṃ gahapatiṃ vā gahapatāniṃ vā cīvaraṃ viññāpetuṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.13.eng: “Monks, if a monk’s robes are stolen or lost, I allow him to ask an unrelated householder for robes.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.14.pli: Yaṃ āvāsaṃ paṭhamaṃ upagacchati, sace tattha hoti saṅghassa vihāracīvaraṃ vā uttarattharaṇaṃ vā bhūmattharaṇaṃ vā bhisicchavi vā, taṃ gahetvā pārupituṃ ‘labhitvā odahissāmī’ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.14.eng: At the first monastery where he arrives, if the Sangha has a communal robe, a bedspread, a floor cover, or a mattress cover, he should take that and put it on, thinking, ‘When I get a robe, I’ll return it.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.14.comm: “A communal robe” renders vihāracīvara, literally, “a dwelling robe”. Since “dwelling robe” is awkward in English, and because these robes did not belong to individual monastics, I prefer the given rendering. “A bedspread” renders uttarattharaṇa. Sp 1.517: Uttarattharaṇanti mañcakassa upari attharaṇakaṁ vuccati, “What is spread on top of a bed is called an uttarattharaṇa.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.15.pli: No ce hoti saṅghassa vihāracīvaraṃ vā uttarattharaṇaṃ vā bhūmattharaṇaṃ vā bhisicchavi vā tiṇena vā paṇṇena vā paṭicchādetvā āgantabbaṃ; na tveva naggena āgantabbaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.15.eng: If there’s none of these things, he should cover up with grass and leaves before going on. He should not go on while naked.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.16.eng: If he does, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.17.pli: Evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ uddiseyyātha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.17.eng: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.18.1.pli: “Yo pana bhikkhu aññātakaṃ gahapatiṃ vā gahapatāniṃ vā cīvaraṃ viññāpeyya, aññatra samayā, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.18.1.eng: ‘If a monk asks an unrelated male or female householder for a robe, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.19.pli: Tatthāyaṃ samayo—acchinnacīvaro vā hoti bhikkhu naṭṭhacīvaro vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.19.eng: These are the appropriate occasions: his robes are stolen or his robes are lost.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.4.eng: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.6.pli: mātito vā pitito vā yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā asambaddho.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.6.eng: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back eight generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.6.comm: Sp 1.505: Tattha yāva sattamā pitāmahayugāti pitupitā pitāmaho, pitāmahassa yugaṁ pitāmahayugaṁ, “In this yāva sattamā pitāmahayuga means: the father of a father is a grandfather. The generation of a grandfather is called a pitāmahayuga.” So the PaIi phrase yāva sattamā pitāmahayuga means “as far as the seventh generation of grandfathers”, that is, eight generations back. This can be counted as follows: (1) one’s grandfather; (2) his father; (3) 2’s father; (4) 3’s father; (5) 4’s father; (6) 5’s father; and (7) 6’s father. This applies to both one’s paternal and maternal grandfathers. This gives a total of 14 ancestors. Anyone who is a descendent of these fourteen is considered a relative. Anyone who is not such a descendent is not regarded as a relative.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.8.eng: any man who lives at home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.8.comm: Agāraṁ is typically rendered as “in a house”. The problem with this is that it is not unallowable for a monastic to live in a building that is the equivalent of a house. What a monastic should not do is own a home and then live there.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.10.eng: any woman who lives at home.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.12.pli: channaṃ cīvarānaṃ aññataraṃ cīvaraṃ vikappanupagaṃ pacchimaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.12.eng: one of the six kinds of robe-cloth, but not smaller than what can be assigned to another.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.12.comm: The six are linen, cotton, silk, wool, sunn hemp, and hemp; see Kd 8:3.1.6. According to Kd 8:21.1.4, the size referred to here is no smaller than 8 by 4 sugataṅgula, “standard fingerbreadths”. For an explanation of the idea of vikappanā, see Appendix of Technical Terms. For the rendering of cīvara as “robe-cloth”, see the same appendix.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.14.eng: unless it is an appropriate occasion.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.16.pli: bhikkhussa cīvaraṃ acchinnaṃ hoti rājūhi vā corehi vā dhuttehi vā, yehi kehici vā acchinnaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.16.eng: a monk’s robe is taken by kings, bandits, scoundrels, or whoever.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.18.pli: bhikkhussa cīvaraṃ agginā vā daḍḍhaṃ hoti, udakena vā vūḷhaṃ hoti, undūrehi vā upacikāhi vā khāyitaṃ hoti, paribhogajiṇṇaṃ vā hoti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.18.eng: a monk’s robe is burned by fire, carried away by flooding, eaten by rats or termites, or worn through use.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.1.eng: If he asks, except on an appropriate occasion, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.2.eng: When he gets the robe-cloth, it becomes subject to relinquishment.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.3.pli: Nissajjitabbaṃ saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā puggalassa vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.3.eng: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.4.eng: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.5.eng: (To be expanded as in Bu NP 1:3.2.5–3.2.29, with appropriate substitutions.)

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.6.pli: idaṃ me, bhante, cīvaraṃ aññātakaṃ gahapatikaṃ, aññatra samayā viññāpitaṃ, nissaggiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.6.eng: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth, which I received after asking an unrelated householder, but not on an appropriate occasion, is to be relinquished.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.7.eng: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.10.eng: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.1.pli: Aññātake aññātakasaññī aññatra samayā cīvaraṃ viññāpeti, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.1.eng: If the person is unrelated and the monk perceives them as such, and he asks them for robe-cloth, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.2.pli: Aññātake vematiko aññatra samayā cīvaraṃ viññāpeti, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.2.eng: If the person is unrelated, but the monk is unsure of it, and he asks them for robe-cloth, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.3.pli: Aññātake ñātakasaññī aññatra samayā cīvaraṃ viññāpeti, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.3.eng: If the person is unrelated, but the monk perceives them as related, and he asks them for robe-cloth, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.4.eng: If the person is related, but the monk perceives them as unrelated, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.5.eng: If the person is related, but the monk is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.6.eng: If the person is related and the monk perceives them as such, there is no offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.2.eng: if it is an appropriate occasion;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.4.eng: if he asks those who have given an invitation;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.5.eng: if he asks for the benefit of someone else;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.6.eng: if it is by means of his own property;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.8.eng: if he is the first offender.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.9.eng: The training rule on asking non-relations, the sixth, is finished.
